metadata.description: Persian ta'arof (تعارف) - ritual politeness system. Critical for cultural translation accuracy.
sources: TAP Persia - The Art of Persian Politeness

taarof_overview.definition: Iranian form of civility emphasizing deference and social rank. Ritual politeness that levels the playing field.
taarof_overview.key_concept: Fighting for the lower hand - abase oneself while exalting the other person
taarof_overview.cultural_note: Ta'arof is NOT deception or hypocrisy. It conveys admiration and gratitude.
taarof_overview.warning_for_translators: Literal translation of ta'arof phrases will cause severe misunderstanding

three_refusals_rule.description: The custom of refusing offers multiple times before accepting
three_refusals_rule.rule: Refuse 2-3 times, then accept on the third/fourth offer

round_1.host: چای میل دارید؟ (Would you like tea?)
round_1.guest_response: نه ممنون، زحمت نکشید (No thank you, don't trouble yourself)
round_1.actual_meaning: Polite first refusal - doesn't mean no

round_2.guest_response: واقعاً نمی‌خواهم (I really don't want any)

examples.warning: If American host offers once and accepts 'no', Iranian guest may want tea but not get it

قابلی_نداره.phrase_fa: قابلی نداره / قابل شما رو نداره
قابلی_نداره.literal: It has no worth / It's not worthy of you
قابلی_نداره.context: Said when giving a gift or offering service
قابلی_نداره.translation_warning: Does NOT mean the item is worthless!

بفرمایید.actual_meaning: Please (go ahead) / Here you go / After you

نوش_جان.literal: May it be sweet to your soul

خواهش_می‌کنم.context: Response to thanks or when offering

قابل_نداره_payment.warning: DOES NOT mean free! This is ta'arof - you must insist on paying
قابل_نداره_payment.typical_scenario: Taxi driver, shopkeeper, or host refuses payment

مهمان_ما_باشید.actual_meaning: Polite offer to pay (may or may not be genuine)
مهمان_ما_باشید.context: At restaurant, offering to pay for someone
مهمان_ما_باشید.note: Must insist 2-3 times before accepting or paying yourself

چاکرم.context: Humble response to thanks or greeting

قربان_شما.literal: May I be sacrificed for you
قربان_شما.actual_meaning: Term of endearment / At your service

فدای_سرت.literal: May I be sacrificed for your head
فدای_سرت.actual_meaning: I care about you deeply / You're dear to me

سرتان_درد_نکنه.context: Thanking someone for listening or helping

دستتان_درد_نکنه.actual_meaning: Thank you for your work (especially handmade)
دستتان_درد_نکنه.context: Thanking for food preparation, crafts, etc.

خسته_نباشید.actual_meaning: Well done / Thank you for your hard work

taxi_payment.driver_literal: No money needed / It's not worthy
taxi_payment.actual_meaning: This is ta'arof - YOU MUST PAY
taxi_payment.correct_response: Insist on paying, put money in their hand
taxi_payment.warning: Foreigners who don't pay will be considered rude

restaurant_bill.behavior: Iranians may physically 'fight' to grab the bill
restaurant_bill.correct_handling: Insist firmly but accept gracefully if they truly insist
restaurant_bill.note: This is normal and expected behavior

exchange.person_b: نه، شما بفرمایید (No, you go ahead)
exchange.resolution: May go back and forth 2-3 times

entering_door.meaning: Showing respect by deferring to other person

food_second_helping.warning: Taking more without being offered is considered impolite

very_formal.note: Third person used for second person (like royal 'we')

switching_formality.rule: Higher status person must offer to switch to informal
switching_formality.phrase: راحت باش (Be comfortable / Let's be informal)
switching_formality.warning: Using informal without permission is disrespectful

general_rules: Add cultural context notes when needed
Consider target audience's familiarity with Persian culture
Preserve the intent, not the words

severity_levels.critical: Will cause serious misunderstanding if translated literally
severity_levels.major: May cause confusion, needs cultural adaptation
severity_levels.minor: Safe to translate somewhat literally with minor adjustments
